title: How to change my perception about everything - Quora

response.answer_text: How do you change your perception? It’s really easy, but also hard at the same time. Here is why (and how): What we define as “our perception” is - in a nutshell - the combination of what information you receive through your senses, and how your brain interprets them. This means there are two filters that reduce the actual reality to your personal perception What your senses pick up and what they don’t.What you brain considers relevant and how it’s being processed.Which already brings us to the answer to your question. If you want to change your perception you need to change how these two filters operate. Pay attention to what you pay attention to. If you only listen to people you agree with, then you won’t be able to diversify your views, ideas, outcomes. If you always watch the same movies, listen to the same music, read the same news outlet, your brain won’t be able to add options to its interpretation of the real world. If you never pause to look around, take a break from your routines, or walk another path, then you your brain will have a hard time figuring out new “ways” for other problems.Once the information arrives at our brain, it will quickly interpret things, make judgements, make decisions, before you even know it. That is something you can’t influence directly. But you can and need to stop right afterwards, to re-asses the situation. You can pause before you say what your brain considers to be the most obvious thing to say. You can consciously override the first impulse of what to do and consider other options.Simple example: You’re driving in your car on a four lane street (two lanes for each direction). On the lane next to you someone all over sudden accelerates to take over, just before both lanes actually merge into one lane. You are a bit surprised by this guy still squeezing past you, and your first thought is: What an idiot to press past you just before the road narrows down to one lane, that’s dangerous. That’s your perception. However, because you are now working on not taking your perception for granted, you actually assess your own driving as well. And oops, turns out you were only going 45 where 60 would have been allowed. You realise that if you had been in that other car, you might have tried to speed past this “snail” as well, before risking to get stuck behind for the next few kilometers. Basically you can re-train your perception by first becoming aware of where you need to stop and change it, then pause to gain time to look at things from various perspectives, and the make a conscious decisions of how you want to proceed from there, whether you want to stick to your initial, automatic assessment, or alter your perception and the subsequent reaction. I hope this makes sense. As I said at the beginning, I don’t know if this will be easy for you or hard. It sounds simple enough, but overriding your well trained brain’s perceptions can be quite hard. Have a look here for some more “technical” insights into perception: Perception - Wikipedia Good luck. 1. Embrace Your Personal Style  If you're like me, you probably dash out the door in the morning wearing any old thing. And that's OK to do most of the time. But if you really want to make a great impression, slow down and take the time to truly get dressed. "When we 'dress up' or wear something we feel really great in, others take notice," Rogers says. "There's something to be said for 'looking the part.' If we can walk into a room with our head held high thanks to a fabulous outfit, your confidence is changing others' perceptions of you in an instant." 2. Practice Giving Off Kinder Vibes  While you certainly don't have to walk around with a 24/7 smile — if that's not your thing — know that it is possible to throw off kind vibes in other ways. "Eyebrows are a big tool for showcasing emotion. Play with them and your expressions," Rogers says. "Eyes are another ... Try it out in the mirror and see how your face portrays what it is you are feeling. And if you can radiate kindness just from your face, people will notice." 3. Put Those Shoulders Back  While the temptation to hunch may be strong, keep in mind that poor posture can make you appear less than confident. So push those shoulders back. "If your shoulders are pushed back, they will appear broader and you will appear taller. It's a power stance and it conveys confidence," Rogers says. "Follow your body's lead and others will immediately respond." 4. Ask Plenty Of Questions  When meeting someone new, or mingling in a group, focus on being that amazing person who asks lots of great questions. "People love sharing their stories," Rogers says. "Stick to a few simple questions (and add a few followups for good measure) and you'll see people instantly start to like you." 5. Make A Healthy Amount Of Eye Contact  It's totally normal to struggle with eye contact, especially if you're a nervous or anxious person. But it is worth working on. "Avoidance of eye contact clues into others that you are not confident or sure of yourself, which probably isn't even true," Rogers says. "It could just be a bad habit. So make sure you practice eye contact in the mirror every day to get used to it." 6. Relax Your Body  While it can be tricky to relax when you're outside your element, it's important to give it a try by slowing down, uncrossing your arms, and relaxing your face. "When you are physically relaxed, other people perceive that you are comfortable with yourself," says confidence expert and trained therapist Karol Ward, LCSW. 7. Tell Yourself "I Matter"  One of the best ways to get good vibes from others is to put them out yourself. So the next time you go out, remind yourself you matter. "Try to do a mental pep talk for yourself prior to an event taking place, and recognize that your presence and your unique strengths and personality and body type are all important," clinical psychologist Dr. Ariane Machin tells Bustle. "This positive and empowered attitude will help you shine." 7. Go Anyway  Shutterstock When trying to make a good impression, it's important to actually show up. So put all sorts of get-togethers and networking events in your calendar and make a point to go. "If we choose not to attend situations or events, we will never have an opportunity to know others and, in effect, they will not get to know us either," Machin says. "Even if you don't feel like going somewhere, take a risk/opportunity and put yourself out there." You'll likely be glad you did. 9. Fill Your Brain With Positive Thoughts  People can totally tell when you're focusing in on negative thoughts. That's why — while it may be easier said that done — it's important to get rid of that negative self-talk and try to be a bit more positive. "If you say something positive to yourself, such as 'You can do it," you will be helping create the scene," says licensed psychologist Marni Amsellem, PhD. "People generally respond well to positivity." 10. Truly Listen To What Others Are Saying  Remember what I said about asking questions? People will remember whether or not you actually listened to them. Which is where the practice of "looping" may come in handy. As author Francis Cole Jones says, "If someone is telling a long, involved story, say, 'I'm just going to interrupt you for a second to make sure I’m following. You said, XYZ happened. Is that right?'" By asking questions like these, it shows the speaker you're listening, and it allows them to clarify anything that was missed. "Either way, they are left thinking you are a great listener." 11. Take Up Plenty Of Space  If you're feeling shy, it's normal to shrink up, fold your arms, or slouch. But in order to make a good impression, you're going to want to take up more space. "Extend your presence," psychotherapist and executive coach Aimee Bernstein tells Bustle. "When you take space energetically, people see you as more powerful and you feel that way yourself." To try it out, stand up taller, put your shoulders back, or gesture more to fill the space. It doesn't have to be over the top, of course. Just enough to show you feel comfortable enough to move round and truly "be" where you are. 12. Be Your Charismatic Self  The more comfortable you can be in any situation, the better. So go ahead and be your charismatic self by laughing, smiling, spinning yarns, or doing whatever is most "you." "Research shows that energy is contagious," Bernstein says. If you go into a room radiating this great energy, people will take notice. And you'll hold a positive spot in their brain as a result. 13. Decide How You'd Like To Define Yourself  Before heading into a situation where you'll need to make a good impression, try filling your brain with a few positive words and use them to define yourself. "Pick three adjectives you want the attendees to use to describe you," Cole Jones says. "Doing this helps to focus your energy." And it helps give off more of those positive vibes. Which, of course, is what this is all about. Whether you're meeting someone for the first time, or doing damage control after a bad first impression, there are ways to change how people perceive you. It just takes a little effort.

Sometimes the only freedom we have is to change our attitude - that changes our perception of life. No matter how badly things are going, you can choose to look for the good ones, even if there are only a few good ones. One of the truths of life is that most of us will not change the way we think, feel and act unless something forces us to do so. Just about every human is like that to some extent, so when things are really awful, we can ask ourselves something like “What to I have to change in my life so that this does not happen again?” Dr. Wayne Dyer had a great saying: “When you change the way you look at things, what you look at changes!” This is a truth at two levels; when you look at situations as having possible good aspects, you see them for the first time; however you also change your environment a bit and from then on a different mix of things comes your way. This is actually built into the way the universe was, is and will be created. Everything is changing, and you can help change it for the better; or for worse. Choose! Love and Above to those who choose to journey towards their Destiny of becoming living Love !

Travel. Spend more or especially less money than you normally would. Meditate. Focus on your breathing for 10 minutes. Read Thich Nhat Hanh or any other beloved teachers. Learn a musical instrument. Watch a documentary on an oppressed group you are unfamiliar with. Do something you think is too risky emotionally, like forgiving a major enemy, or confronting someone's destructive behavior. Expand your comfort zone. Treat yourself better (improve eating, sleeping, and exercise). Start praying or stop praying. Repeat things. Practice them over and over again and notice how things change. Watch videos of contact improvisation or other art forms that challenge social conventions. Give them a try. Ask people what they think of themselves, and what they think of you. Learn to sing. Contemplate the fundamental worth of each living being. Embrace diversity. Spend time in nature more frequently. Change your mode of transportation (car, bicycle, train). Find a decent therapist. Fast. Go to a concert of your favorite artist. Get help managing addictive or destructive behaviors. Pay attention to your dreams, both what happens while sleeping, and also your heart's greatest desires.

There are physical limits to our ability to observe, and they can become a handicap. With being surrounded by many others of equal capability, you can win, if you play your cards right. This playing your cards right is not a matter of using any scary tactics. It is a matter of balancing your view of the world to take in all possible views. Doing that requires a matter of patience and persistence. There is a Japanese method for doing that. It will resolve your daily life questions and your visual ability questions. Complete disaster was averted in the nick of time by learning-using a few realities more fundamental than my personal perspectives. They are described in the Nichiren Buddhism, as taught by the Soka Gakkai Interntaional. -Life is better when you pay attention. -You are unique, as is every other being. -You are an aspect of everything, as is every other being. _Causes produce effects. -Lives change, yet Life persists. -Your path, no matter how similar it may seem on the surface, will never be exactly what anyone else’s will be, is, or has been. Beyond that, you can shine with brilliance in your chosen environment. It's not as hard as it seems, if you are willing to learn what everybody already knows in bits, and pieces. You can use it, in a compact form to infuse your life with wisdom, and awareness. You become more effective, and make better use of your innate abilities. How? Base yourself on what is true for anyone, anywhere, anytime, under any circumstances. Then, your personal set of responses will be consistent with reality. There will be fewer collisions. The bedrock of reality is a set of simple to explain, yet difficult to accept realities. They are simple because that is the nature of fundamentals. They are hard to accept because they bypass, and challenge, so many assumptions to which we are habituated. This is a condensed description -Pay attention. Respect. Be equal to. Nam -You are an aspect of everything, and so is every other being. Myo -You are unique, and so is every other being. Ho -Causes produce effects, for all of us. You can wake up from mistaken views at any time. Renge -Lives change, Yet, Life goes on. Kyo Those who keep these simple realities in mind, simultaneously, will have fewer accidents, and be able to develop better lives. These consistently real truths are intuitively obvious, yet we often forget one, or more, when we react. Our emotional past, and the inherited tendencies from our ancestors get in the way of currently practical, rational thought. We can protect our good sense when we make efforts to infuse these fundamentals into our lives. The infusion is easier when the basic reality is packaged conveniently into six words. (Nam Myoho Renge Kyo). They are spoken in the language of the founder, Nichiren of thirteenth century Japan. William Ranger's post in William Who controls you?

Our perceptions arise from our beliefs or habitual thoughts. Constructive perceptions, the tendency to see the good in people, things, or situations, or to view compassionately, spring from positive beliefs. For instance, if you believe the world is an unsafe place, and that love is an illusion, you will likely view people with suspicion, irrespective of their good intention. So, you need to challenge and discard your irrational thoughts and beliefs, for you to change your perceptions for the better. When we discard our fearful beliefs, and choose Love instead, our perception will change.

Last week I was on the death anniversary of my mom's maternal uncle. Now in Hindu society, it is a rule to throw away all the remaining foods cooked on the 13th day after the death. From my mom's house, a ton of foods was destined to be thrown in the garbage, that day. I was shell-shocked when I saw that. Millions of people are dying every day due to hunger and we are throwing away those foods, only because it is the reality, people do that, it has been a tradition? I protested I did not care whatever my family members would think about myself but I urged this to my grandfather and my own maternal uncle. My maternal uncle responded to somewhat to my opinions but my grandfather did not. “The beggars won't even eat this food, it is unholy”, my grandfather commented. I smiled and reply, “Is it more unholy than death?”. Grandfather was mum, he did not have words to argue that. I and my maternal uncle took that food and deposited to a nearby dhaba, from where local NGOs collect food to feed the beggars. My maternal uncle had his links and he really appreciated me for this step. We did not tell this at home but I am glad that I could feed a few beggars with that food. So yes, I have altered the perception of reality and have seen the truth behind it. It is beautiful as well as exceptional. Changing is another word for humanism. We are born to evolve not to flow with reality. Thanks for reading.

Q: Can you control your perception of reality? Totally…changing your beliefs, changes your perception. As perception is reality, changing one’s beliefs controls not only perception but reality itself. A good example is that if something in your past occurred that you considered a negative event, upon receiving additional information anent the event, it is seen in a positive light. Your beliefs have changed due to your changed perception of the event and you see how it turned out to be for your betterment. The event occurs but its reality is different, due to your control of perception. Perception is reality. Perception is the only way to control reality. Change your perception, change your reality.

Question: How do I change reality?Answer: Whose reality?  The reality of the universe, the reality of your family, your own reality? Reality is a misnomer.  What we perceive to be real becomes our reality.  There have been numerous studies in which a group of people where shown a series of events as a group.  Afterwards they were asked a series of questions to test their perception of what occurred.  People interpreted what they saw differently.  They were asked to support their answers and indicate how sure they were of their answers.  It is amazing how eyewitness accounts of an event differ by how people perceived the event. The only reality that you can affect is your own.  If there is something in your life, your reality, that displeases your then take action to change those aspect.  Waiting on others to change your reality is futile and wasteful.  Your reality is not set in stone and should not be dictated by others.  The only thing that can change your reality is ACTION.  Do something different.  Doing the same thing and expecting different results is the definition of insanity.  If you want change, do something different.

There is no fixed reality. Nothing out there is real - only convenient. :)So…To change the reality that you experience it is necessary to change your self first. The difference between a good day and a bad day is attitude. This is the easiest thing to change. :) Behaviour can be changed too. Try brushing your teeth with the other hand. Try writing or eating with your left hand. Part your hair on the other side of your head. Try walking clockwise around the block with your dog rather than anti-clockwise. Try doing things differently. When you start acting and behaving differently then you should notice reality has changed for you. Not much will be familiar to you - and you will notice new opportunities in your life. :) give it a try.

Practice focusing as well as taking in the whole of the scenery, reminding yourself using all your five senses that you are in fact awake and a part of reality. As long as you make a conscious effort to notice and acknowledge what is around you, you will naturally do a scan of your surroundings and pick up on interesting details for later in case you need them. Just work on reminding yourself to breathe and see clearly at a regular basis and soon enough it will become second nature.

You could read about what perception is and how it evolves. I think the star in that field is Donald Hoffman. There is always the debate, if you read what the experts are discussing, over whether perception evolved to produce a more truthful picture or for fitness of our body. Do you wish to improve your thinking or your body, or is there a third thing that you wish to improve? Perhaps you are a policeman or an attorney and you need to become more cognizant of your environment so you can use the clues around you to solve mysteries or cases. In that case, aren’t you preparing to memorize every detail of a scene? There might be some training exercises you can do for that. What about this idea: look at an image, a room full of things, for example, and then take away the image and practice by recalling the number of objects that were in the image?
